passages.text: Auction Preview: China, Korea, Philippines, Indonesia, Thailand, India & Malaysia

Upcoming Auctions – China: CGB supply pressure set to moderate in 4Q; Korea: KTB supply to remain elevated in 2026; Philippines: Constructive on supply dynamics, but less dovish BSP statement keeps us selective on levels to re-engage; Indonesia: Auction demand expected to stay firm, but some caution may be warranted; Malaysia: Moderation in auction demand in the last two weeks, but we expect robust bond performance to return; Thailand: Moderate auction demand likely. India: Biased for a steeper curve; auctions likely to be modest.

Gordon Goh AC
+65-6657-4150

With thanks to
Stanley Ren
Figure 1. Upcoming Auctions for Next Two Weeks

Citi Research is a division of Citigroup Global Markets Inc. (the "Firm"), which does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the Firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. Certain products (not inconsistent with the author's published research) are available only on Citi's portals.

China: CGB supply pressure set to moderate in 4Q. For the next two weeks, there will be four regular CGB issuances (see issuance calendar above for more details). Overall CGB supply this year has exhibited a notably front- loaded profile, with \(75\%\) of the RMB 13.9tn quota already utilized, compared to a historical average of \(60\%\) over the preceding three years. On the front of ultra- long tenor special CGB issuance, YTD issuance by the end of Aug'25 has reached RMB 1tn, roughly \(77\%\) of RMB 1.3tn target quota. With five ultra- long tenor special CGB issuances left to be issued until early Oct, CGB supply pressure is set to moderate in 4Q. On the recent demand dynamics, we note that the bid- to- cover on the most recent 10y CGB issuance dropped significantly to 2.58, marking the new low over its 12m range.

We assess this could be partly attributed to the VAT reinstatement on interest income from government bonds. To recap, The MoF and State administration of Taxation announced that value- added tax (VAT) will be reinstated on interest income from government bonds, local government bonds, and financial bonds issued from Aug \(8^{\text{th}}\) onwards; bonds issued before August \(8^{\text{th}}\) will retain their VAT- exempt status until maturity. Additionally, for the reopening issuance of bonds originally issued before Aug \(8^{\text{th}}\) , VAT exemption will remain applicable until maturity date of the bonds. Overall, we believe there is some rotation of money happening between bonds and equities both onshore as well as offshore which is pushing yields higher. However, unless we see a big move higher in inflation, the bias would be to re- engage in long 10y CGB at around \(2\%\) levels. Meanwhile, we remain long in 1y NCD with FX hedge (entry: 2.01%, current 1.61% as of 15:01pm HKT Aug 29th 2025).

Korea: KTB supply to remain elevated in 2026. KTB issuance target is set at KRW 232tn for 2026, vs. this year's KRW 231.1tn (after the second supplementary budget), and original budget of KRW 197.6tn. Net issuance is expected to reach KRW 115.7tn in 2026, increased by KRW 2.1tn from this year. Additionally, the government will have quasi- sovereign issuances up to KRW 40tn, including KRW 15tn Advanced Strategic Industry Fund Bonds, KRW 10tn won Supply Chain Stabilization Fund Bonds, and KRW 13.7tn KRW- denominated FX stabilization Bonds. Accordingly, fiscal deficit ratio is expected to reach \(4\%\) of GDP, effectively nullifying the fiscal rule pursued by the Yoon Suk- yeol administration that capped the ratio at \(3.0\%\) , as noted by our economist (link).

Looking ahead, on the interplay between monetary and fiscal policy, it's clear to us that the government is keen on having easier fiscal policy to push through its agenda. The rate hold decision this week resonates with our view that monetary policy is likely to take a backseat for now even though housing prices have continued to come off. However, we uphold the view that the BOK is still in a rate cutting cycle. The rate hold decision this week have further raised the chances for a 25bp cut to materialize in the next few months, in our view. It is also likely that we get something more but for that to happen we would need concrete signs of economic slowdown (despite a more active fiscal policy) and softer inflation prints on a sustainable basis. Accordingly, we remain received in 1y1y KRW NDIRS (entry: 2.365%, current: 2.325% as of 15:01pm HKT Aug 29th 2025).

Indonesia: Auction demand expected to stay firm, but some caution may be warranted. We saw another strong round of incoming bids at this week's conventional auction. Incoming bids totaled IDR 126tn, with IDR 30tn awarded, less than the IDR 32tn awarded between Jul to early Aug. We have been overweight IndoGBs in our model portfolio since April. The flattening of the money- market curve and maturities of SRBI have meant that price of liquidity has come down and quantity of liquidity has gone up. This has triggered huge amount of buying from offshore investors (both real money and fast money). We believe this rally in
issuance in Sep and likelihood of reduced auction sizes for Q4. Our expectations remain for any supply reduction to come in the \(

dynamics shall keep any uptick in Thai yields rather shallow. While today's announced dismissal of PM Paetongtarn was largely expected, it does leave uncertainty elevated for domestic politics with the likely options being the selection of new PM from the candidate pool of 2023 election or dissolving the House with General Elections called early. For now, we remain biased towards a steeper curve and are received 1s3s10s Thai Swaps (Current spreads: - 47bp as of 17:30 SGT, 29 Aug'25).

India: Biased for a steeper curve; auctions likely to be modest. The policy construct in India is pretty simple. The RBI has eased by 100 bps this year and at present, it doesn't seem there is much room to ease based on real rates on an ex- ante basis. Some concerns around INR from a policy differential point of view might be creeping in as well. We believe this leaves the policymakers to indulge in easing through fiscal policy and FX.

On fiscal policy, we wrote that Indian policymakers are likely to offset external challenges through more pro- active fiscal policy now that S&P upgrade is behind us. Because at the end of the day, maintaining growth is as important from a debt sustainability point of view. Indeed, the government came out with GST reform measures right after and we believe more could be on the plate if external challenges increase. In the past few days, we have seen an aggressive move higher in the fixed income curve in a bear steepening fashion and this could continue, in our view. We are paid 3m fwd 1s5s INR NDOIS (Currently: +27.8bp; pricing as of 17:30 SGT, 29 Aug'25).

For the purposes of disclosing recommendations other than for equity (whose definitions can be found in the corresponding disclosure sections), "Buy" means a positive directional trade idea; "Sell" means a negative directional trade idea; and "Relative Value" means any trade idea which does not have a clear direction to the investment strategy.
